newsitem.title: USA: Fund manager eyes stock with low ratios -- Barron's.
newsitem.headline: Fund manager eyes stock with low ratios -- Barron's.

text.p: Fund manager Jim O'Shaughnessy, president of O'Shaughnessy Capital Management, has started four funds based around a strategy of buying stocks with low price-to-book ratios and low price-to-sales ratios, according to a weekly U.S. business newspaper.
The price-to-sales ratio is calculated by dividing a company's stock market value by its annual revenue.

"If investors were rational, they wouldn't pay $10 or $20 for every dollar of a company's sales," O'Shaughnessy was quoted as saying in Barron's February 17 issue. "But investors get captivated by stories, whether it be Netscape Communications Corp or Planet Hollywood International Inc."
Most companies with rich valuations tended to fare badly versus the overall market, he said.
The stocks O'Shaughnessy was avoiding this year included Cascade Communications Corp, CyberCash Inc, Yahoo! Inc and Planet Hollywood, the paper said.
His favourites include Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc, Gateway 2000 Inc and Ethan Allen Interiors Inc, Barron's said.
